source: from pyspark.sql.types import StructType, StructField, StringType

# Define expected schema for JSON inside Body
body_schema = StructType([
    StructField("time", StringType()),
    StructField("operationName", StringType()),
    StructField("category", StringType()),
    StructField("resourceId", StringType()),
    StructField("level", StringType()),
    StructField("location", StringType())

# Parse the Body column from binary to JSON and extract fields
df_parsed = df_raw.withColumn("log", from_json(col("Body").cast("string"), body_schema))

# Select useful fields
df_clean = df_parsed.select(
    col("log.time").alias("LogTime"),
    col("log.operationName").alias("Operation"),
    col("log.category").alias("Category"),
    col("log.level").alias("Severity"),
    col("log.resourceId").alias("ResourceId"),
    col("log.location").alias("Location")
)

# Show cleaned data
df_clean.show(10)

# Step 1: Add the SQL connector to Spark session
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

spark = SparkSession.builder \
    .appName("WriteToSQL") \
    .config("spark.jars.packages", "com.microsoft.azure:spark-mssql-connector_2.12:1.2.0") \
    .getOrCreate()

# Step 2: Define connection info
workspace_name = "asa-workshop-first-test"
sql_pool_name = "DedicatedP1"
username = "sqladminuser@asa-workshop-first-test"  # ← Your SQL admin username
password = "Passuneverc022/#"

jdbc_url = f"jdbc:sqlserver://{workspace_name}.sql.azuresynapse.net:1433;databaseName={sql_pool_name};user={username};password={password};encrypt=true;trustServerCertificate=false;hostNameInCertificate=*.sql.azuresynapse.net;loginTimeout=30;"

# Step 3: Write DataFrame to SQL pool
df_clean.write \
    .format("com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.spark") \
    .mode("append") \
    .option("url", jdbc_url) \
    .option("dbtable", "dbo.EventHubLogs") \
    .save()

print("✅ Successfully wrote data to SQL pool!")
